LaunW881.question: An aircraft having sustained damage while on the territory of a Contracting State other than the State of Registry may fly without fare-paying passengers to an airport at which it can be restored to an airworthy condition if:

options.text: it receives permission of the State of Registry.
it receives permission from the Contracting State where the damage occurred.
it receives permission from the manufacturer of the aircraft.
the repair works may be done at an airport that is not more than 250 NM away.

shISCR3m.question: An aircraft is being subjected to unlawful interference in non RVSM airspaceThe pilot is forced to divert from the cleared track and/or cruising level without being able to communicate this to ATSThe pilot should attempt to

options.text: proceed at a level which differs from the cruising level normally used for IFR flights in that area by 1 000 ft above FL 290, or 500 ft below FL 290.
slow the speed of the aircraft down to minimum, squawk A 7700 and declare emergency on 121.5 MHz.
commence as soon as possible an emergency descent in order to minimise the difference between cabin pressure and outside pressure.
fly the emergency triangle and try to establish radiotelephony contact with the interference coordinator of the appropriate ATS unit on 121.5 MHz.

uonXfLMQ.question:
The aircraft has made a complete stop on the apron
When leaving the aircraft, one of the passengers walks into the trailing edge of the wing and gets seriously injured.

options.text: This is an accident. The crew must follow the procedure relevant for this case.
This is an irregularity in the handling. The handling agent must inform his insurance company.
This is an incident. The PIC must report it to the airport authority within the next 48 hours.

This is a matter of passenger insurance as the flight is terminated and the aeroplane door is open. The airport operator or the company in charge of the handling shall establish a report for the insurance company.

uU5hTrGN.question: What is the correct code for unlawful interference in flight?

varbnckf.question: When an aircraft is subjected to unlawful interference, the pilot-in-command shall attempt to indicate the situation to ATC by setting the transponder to Mode A, code..

66MFfszA.question: What instructions would be given to an aircraft subject to unlawful interference (hi-jack)?

options.text: Directed to an isolated parking spot
Directed to a normal terminal so the terrorists would believe everything was normal
Directed to park in a normal terminal so the passengers could be offloaded with maximum efficiency
Directed to park on the runway

T82T1h3g.question: Where would a hijacked aircraft be parked after landing?

options.text: At an isolated parking slot
Near the terminal
Near the Security and Rescue services
Near the Rescue Services

vAhQSN2V.question: What is a State required to do regarding the aeroplane which has been unlawfully interfered with when it lands?

options.text: The contracting States will make provisions to ensure that an aircraft affected by an unlawful seizure act which has landed in their territory, would be detained on the ground, unless to do so would prejudice human life.
The ICAO Annex 17 does not recognize the need for consultations between the State where an aircraft affected by an unlawful interference act has landed and the aircraft operator's State.
The contracting States will not assist with the provision of navigation aids, air transit services, etc... to an aircraft affected by an unlawful seizure act.
The contracting States will make provisions to ensure that an aircraft affected by an unlawful seizure act which has landed in their territory, would be detained on the ground in all cases.

Zjapyk3S.question: According to ICAO Annex 14 recommendations, aircraft stand markings should be provided

options.text: for designated parking positions on a paved apron and on a de-icing/anti-icing facility.
for designated parking positions on any apron and on a de-icing/anti-icing facility.
only for designated parking positions on a paved apron.
only for designated parking positions on any apron.

hqXI9fIb.question: Aircraft stand markings should be provided for;

options.text: Designated parking positions on a paved apron and on a de-icing facility.
Designated parking positions on a paved apron only
Only designated parking positions on any apron
Designated parking positions only

UydYyHDC.question: When cargo, unaccompanied baggage or stores are not unladen at their intended destination but are unladen at another international airport, the Contracting State where the unloading takes place, if satisfied that there has been no gross negligence or carelessness by the operator:

options.text: shall not impose penalties, fines, customs duties and taxes on the operator.
shall not impose penalties and fines but customs duties and taxes on the operator.
shall not impose penalties, fines and custom duties but taxes on the operator.
shall not impose penalties, fines and taxes but custom duties on the operator.

8jGLdDtM.question: Which are the national security programme requirements that an operator`s security programme shall meet?  The requirements from

options.text: any State from which the operator is flying.
the State of the Operator.
the aircraft`s State of Registry.
the United Nations` security programme.

8Ky2v9ql.question: Who assists the authority in coordinating the implementation of security controls and procedures, as specified in the airport security programme?

options.text: The Airport Security Committee.
The European Union`s security policy delegate.
The local police department.
The Air Force.

FcP6gAWH.question: For the transport of potentially disruptive passengers some supplementary safeguards are to be observed, such as:

options.text: boarding prior to all passengers.
the boarding procedure will be at the pilot in command discretion.
the boarding has to be done at the State's discretion.
boarding after all other passengers.

NIGCS2mk.question: How is the inspection of those interior and accessible exterior parts of the aircraft in order to detect prohibited articles that jeopardize the security of the aircraft called?

options.text: Aircraft security search.
Screening.
Security control.
Pre-flight check.

7T4gOHaR.question: What actions should be taken during a flight with a lawful person on board?

options.text: Inform the PIC and the company.
Ask the PIC to inform the company.
Ask the PIC and the company.
Inform PIC to ask the company.

W9aE8zXe.question: In accordance with Annex 17, what are the requirements when individuals who have been subject of judicial or administrative proceedings are required to travel?

options.text: The operator and PIC must be informed.
Request permission from the operator and inform the PIC.
Request permission from both the operator and the PIC.
Inform the operator and request permission from the PIC.

NDQpq59K.question: In an emergency scenario, all the avionics are out and there is no contact established with ATS. In order to indicate that something is wrong, the PIC should proceed to a level which differs from normally used cruising levels for IFR flight by:

options.text: 500 ft different each flight level 1 000 ft apart.
1 000 ft different each flight level 1 000 ft apart.
1 000 ft different each flight level 500 ft apart.
2 000 ft different each flight level 1 300 ft apart.

KgkRKzNl.question: In an emergency scenario, all the avionics are out and there is no contact established with ATS. In order to indicate that something is wrong, the PIC should proceed to a level which differs from normally used cruising levels for IFR flight by:

options.text: 150 m different each flight level 300 m apart.
300 m different each flight level 300 m apart.
600 m different each flight level 300 m apart.
300 m different each flight level 150 m apart.

DPzNAK59.question: When must the flight deck door be closed and locked?

options.text: From the time all external doors are closed following embarkation until any such door is opened for disembarkation.
From the time the engines are running until the engines are shutdown after flight.
From the time when the outside check has been completed and both pilots are in the cockpit preparing for departure.
From the time when entering the runway for take-off until the time when leaving the runway after landing.

bbz3nNOs.question: According ICAO Annex 2, what should a pilot in command do in a situation of unlawful interference (hijacking)?

options.text: Attempt to land as soon as practicable.
Fly a holding pattern at the lowest FL possible.
Overpower the hijacker.
Select mode A code 7600.

kQZe5RN7.question: A pilot is taxiing when someone tries to enter the coockpit. What shall the pilot do?

options.text: He/she must remain as far away from other aircraft as possible and taxi to a designated or isolated parking area in accordance with local instructions.
He/she must take-off and fly towards an isolated airfield.
He/she must taxi towards the terminal areas so that help can be obtained as soon as possible.
He/she must always immediately initiate an emergency evacuation.

ZfxXjsbT.question: In accordance with ICAO PANS-ATM, in case of unlawful interference, where should the aircraft be instructed to taxi to after landing?

options.text: Designated isolated parking position.
Designated area at a safe distance from the fire station.
Parking position near the security authorities.
End of the landing runway.

ACi8DQDY.question: A State shall take adequate measures for the safety of passengers and crew of an aircraft which is subjected to an act of unlawful interference

options.text: until their journey can be continued.
and arrange for them to return to their country of origin.
during a period of investigation.
if is requested by an individual passenger.

VxzI19Lx.question: According to ICAO Annex 17 (Security), a German airline must establish an operator security programme in writing and...

options.text: implement and maintain it. The programme must comply with the national civil aviation security programme of Germany.
implement and maintain it. The programme must comply with the European aviation security programme of EASA.
hand deliver it to the competent authority. The programme must comply with the international aviation security programme of ICAO.
hand deliver it to the competent authority. The programme must comply with the international civil aviation transport airline security programme of IATA.

IsY1rpG0.question: According to ICAO Annex 6 and considering passenger-carrying aeroplanes that must be equipped with an approved flight crew compartment door designed to resist penetration by small arms fire and intrusions unauthorised persons, this door must be capable of being locked and unlocked from...

options.text: Either pilot's seat.
The captain's seat only.
The pilot's seats and by maintenance personnel on the ground.
The pilot's and flight attendant's seats.

weFUy3ho.question: In relation to the national security programme, an aircraft operator shall confirm its security procedures to:

options.text: any state from which the operator is providing service.
the state of the operator.
the state of the manufacturer.
the state of registry.

AANNfwuN.question: A Contracting State shall ensure that commercial air transport operators providing services from its State have established, implemented and maintained a..

options.text: written operator security programme.
verbal operator security programme.
loadmaster screening checklist.
security screening checklist.

x65hrmUE.question: What should the PIC do if the aircraft is subject to unlawful interference and if he/she is unable to notify an ATS unit?

options.text: Proceed in accordance with procedures promulgated in ICAO Doc 7030.
Climb or descent 500 ft if separation is 2 000.
Squawk 7700.
Climb or descent 200 ft if separation is 1 000 ft.

mnYBiVLq.question: Which of the following is part of the 'security restricted area'? (ICAO Annex 17 / (EC) No 300/**2 008**)

options.text: All commercial aviation passenger departure areas between the screening checkpoint and the aircraft.
The airside area, extending 5 NM away from the airport.
The airport buildings area, where PAX have access.
The baggage and PAX check-in area.

BhEh5lqz.question: Which of the following is part of the 'security restricted area'? (ICAO Annex 17 / (EC) No 300/**2 008**)

options.text: The airside catering and aircraft cleaning premises.
The airside area, extending 5 NM away from the airport.
The airport buildings area, where PAX have access.
The baggage and PAX check-in area.

MZWYALUq.question: According to ICAO Annex 17, what is the definition of ‘Security Control’?

options.text: A means by which the introduction of weapons, explosives or other dangerous devices, articles or substances which may be used to commit an act of unlawful interference can be prevented.
A check on a person’s identity and previous experience including where legally permissible, any criminal history.

The application of technical or other means which are intended to identify and/or detect weapons, explosives or other dangerous devices, articles or substances which may be used to commit an act of unlawful interference.
A secret or public trial of an aviation security measure which simulates an attempt to commit an unlawful act.

qiPPWfpF.question: You are the pilot-in-command of an aircraft subjected to unlawful interference. Due to the circumstances you are obliged to deviate from the assigned track and cruising level. It is expected that you will try to broadcast warnings and follow applicable special procedures established in Regional Agreements. If no such procedures have been established you should proceed at a level which differs from those normally used by IFR flights by:

options.text: 1 000 ft above FL410.
500 ft above FL410.
500 ft above FL290 (Non RVSM).
1 000 ft above FL290 (RVSM).

BQzQ29xY.question: Where a designated parking bay is not provided at an aerodrome for the use by aircraft that have been subject to unlawful interference, what is the minimum distance from other parking areas or installations that such aircraft may be parked?

VkamsBga.question: In case of an emergency a pilot needs to act in a correct way. All the avionics is out and can not make contact with ATS. What level might the PIC choose to signify that something is wrong?

options.text: 500 ft different each flight level 1 000 ft apart
1 000 ft different each flight level 500 ft apart
1 000 ft different each flight level 1 000 ft apart
2 000 ft different each flight level 1 300 ft apart

EDmSkh1i.question: Who is responsible for the implementation of an 'operator security programme'  in Germany?

options.text: German authority, written.
ICAO, oraly.
EASA, written
IATA, oraly.

zDRNHVXF.question: According to ICAO Annex 17, to what does the following definition correspond to?"An inspection of the interior of an aircraft to which passengers may have had access and an inspection of the hold for the purposes of discovering suspicious objects, weapons, explosives or other dangerous devices, articles and substances."

options.text: Aircraft security check.
Screening.
Security control.
Aircraft pre-flight check.

CFS4vgq6.question:
For security reasons, what objects listed below shall NOT be introduced, by any means whatsoever, on board an aircraft that is engaged in international civil aviation according to ICAO Annex 17?
1. Weapons, the carriage of which is NOT authorised. 
 2. Electronic devices with partially charged batteries. 
 3. Explosives that may be used to commit an unlawful act. 
 4. Liquids purchased outside of the airside zone of the aerodrome.

options.text: 1 and 3.
1 and 4.
2 and 3.

NfcB8q1k.question: The carriage of weapons on a civil aircraft is possible, if specific requirements are met. Which of the following conditions permit a weapon to be carried on an aircraft?

options.text: When the weapon is unloaded and stowed in a place which is not accessible to any person during flight.
When the weapon is carried by a flight crew member, holding a valid firearms permission.
When the weapon is carried by a professional hunter who holds a firearms permit with an ICAO endorsement.
When the weapon is carried by an in-flight security officer without notification to the flight crew.

nboNhLKv.question: According to ICAO Annex 2, what should the pilot in command do under a state of unlawful interference?

options.text: Land as soon as practicable.
Attempt to fight the hijacker.
Set mode A code 7600.
Begin circling at the lowest altitude possible.

t54RzChk.question: When mixing or contact does take place between passengers subjected to security control and other persons not subjected to such control after the security screening points at airports serving international civil aviation have been passed:

options.text: the passengers concerned and their cabin baggage shall be re-screened before boarding an aircraft.
only the passengers are to be re-screened.
the persons not subjected to security control shall be identified.
only the passengers cabin baggage are to be re-screened.

YyqLrdo4.question: According to ICAO Annex 17, when a passenger is obliged to travel because he/she has been the subject of judicial proceedings, the Competent Authority shall ensure that the...

options.text: aircraft operator and the Pilot-in-Command are informed.
relevant ATC services and the Pilot-in-Command are informed.
aircraft operator and the Civil Aviation Authority are informed.
aircraft operator and the relevant ATC services are informed.
A means by which the introduction of weapons, explosives or other dangerous devices, articles or substances which may be used to commit an act of unlawful interference can be prevented.

The application of technical or other means which are intended to identify and/or detect weapons, explosives or other dangerous devices, articles or substances which may be used to commit an act of unlawful interference.
A check on a person’s identity and previous experience including where legally permissible, any criminal history.
A secret or public trial of an aviation security measure which simulates an attempt to commit an unlawful act.

T9SBAnCy.question: An aircraft which is subjected to unlawful seizure during taxi should stop in a designated area and wait for assistance. It shall not depart, unless its departure is necessitated by...

options.text: the overriding duty to protect human life.
the lack of security at the airport.
the lack of refuelling capabilities.
the overriding duty to protect air traffic services.

zB9BXvZO.question: When an aircraft subjected to an act of unlawful interference must depart from its assigned track or its assigned cruising level without being able to make radiotelephony contact with ATS, what should the pilot-in-command do, whenever possible?

options.text: Proceed in accordance with applicable special procedures for in-flight contingencies, where such procedures have been established and promulgated in the Regional Supplementary Procedures (Doc 7030).
Proceed at a level which differs from the cruising levels normally used for IFR flight by 75 m (250 ft) in an area where a vertical separation minimum of 300 m (1000 ft) is applied.
Proceed at a level which differs from the cruising levels normally used for IFR flight by 150 m (500 ft) in an area where a vertical separation minimum of 600 m (2000 ft) is applied.
Set code 7700 on the transponder.

R88cT7QU.question: What should a pilot do if he/she is unable to contact ATC in the case of an unlawful interference at FL290 in RVSM airspace?

options.text: Climb or descend 500 ft.
Climb 1 000 ft or descend 500 ft.
Climb or descend 1 000 ft.
Descend to 10 000 ft.

pbHkPRGY.question: Who must be informed if there are any law enforcement officers, who carry weapons, are on board?

options.text: The pilot-in-command is notified as to the number of armed persons and their seat location.
The operator is notified as to the number of armed persons.
The pilot-in-command is notified as to the number of armed persons.
The operator is notified as to the number of armed persons and their seat location.

d5SpbDSB.question: What is true when an armed safety officer is to travel with a loaded firearm in accordance with their duties?

options.text: This requires a special authorization.
This does not require a special authorization.
The PIC shall not be informed.
The officer is not able to travel when armed.

DsYU1C3S.question: When a passenger is obliged to travel due to judicial proceedings, each Contracting State shall ensure that

options.text: The aircraft operator and the pilot-in-command are informed.
The pilot-in-command is informed.
The aircraft operator is asked for permission and the pilot-in-command is informed.
The aircraft operator and the pilot-in-command are asked for permission.

K26C4Wxk.question: How far away from other aircraft and buildings should the pilot park the aircraft if a bomb threat is suspected?

NbDqoGx6.question: If an aircraft is subject to unlawful interference, the pilot should park:

options.text: in an isolated area.
next to ambulance and security vehicles.
at the gate.
close to the terminal so that action forces can reach the aircraft without being noticed by the hijackers.

0vFyy7Dq.question: A passenger's sporting shotgun may be carried on an aircraft:

options.text: with the operator's permission, the commander's knowledge, unloaded and in a place where the passengers have no access.
with the operator's permission.
with the commander's permission, unloaded in an overhead locker.
but not if it is a public transport flight.

BfrrqRZV.question: Definition of "Security" in accordance with ICAO Annex 17, is a combination of measures:

options.text: and human and material resources intended to safeguard international civil aviation against acts of unlawful interference.
intended to safeguard international civil aviation against acts of unlawful interference.
intended to safeguard civil aviation against acts of unlawful interference.
and human and material resources intended to safeguard international civil aviation.

ptDnamOI.question: Security – Assistance to an aircraft following an act of unlawful seizure – A State shall provide assistance to an aircraft subjected to an act of unlawful seizure. This assistance shall include...

options.text: provision of navigation aids, air traffic services and permission to land.
provision of navigation aids, air traffic services, permission to land and refuelling.
permission to land and catering for passengers.
provision of navigation aids, air traffic services, permission to land and catering for passengers.

GEeJKFyY.question: Security – The national civil aviation security programme is established by..

options.text: each Contracting State.
ECAC.
ICAO.
ICAO and other organisations, including the Contracting State concerned.

3Fmh0ybR.question: Each Contracting State in which an aircraft subjected to an act of unlawful interference has landed shall notify by the most expeditious means the State of Registry of the aircraft and the State of the Operator of the landing and shall similarly transmit by the most expeditious means all other relevant information to:

options.text: the two above-mentioned States, each State whose citizens suffered fatalities or injuries, each State whose citizens were detained as hostages, each Contracting State whose citizens are known to be on board the aircraft, and the International Civil Aviation Organization.
the two above-mentioned States, each State whose citizens suffered fatalities or injuries, and the International Civil Aviation Organization.
the two above-mentioned States, and each State whose citizens suffered fatalities or injuries.
the two above-mentioned States, each Contracting State whose citizens are known to be on board the aircraft, and the International Civil Aviation Organization.

hyyLFaLM.question: Each Contracting State shall ensure that commercial air transport operators providing service from that state have...

options.text: a written operator security programme.
a loadmaster checklist.
an oral security programme.
a security checklist.

3dRGMJTw.question: Refer to the ICAO definitions. Airside is...

options.text: the movement area of an airport, adjacent terrain and buildings or portions thereof, access to which is controlled.
that part of an aerodrome to be used for the take-off, landing and taxiing of aircraft, excluding aprons.
that part of an aerodrome to be used for the take-off, landing and taxiing of aircraft, consisting of the manoeuvring area and the apron(s).
a defined area, on a land aerodrome, intended to accommodate aircraft for purposes of loading or unloading passengers, mail or cargo, fuelling, parking or maintenance.

qyzwq99j.question: According to ICAO Doc 4444 (PANS-ATM), once on the ground, an aircraft known to be the subject of unlawful interference should be instructed to...

options.text: taxi to a designated or isolated parking area.
remain on the runway and stay clear of any taxiways.
keep one engine running at all times.
switch off all its exterior lights.

4zAyiE50.question: What is meant by the term 'unidentified baggage' when referring to (EC) No 300/**2008**) or ICAO Annex 17?

options.text: Baggage at an airport, with or without a baggage tag, which is not picked up by or identified with a passenger.
Baggage, carried in the hold of an aircraft, which has been checked in for a flight by a passenger travelling on that same flight.
Baggage intended for carriage in the hold of an aircraft.
Baggage in an aircraft cabin or cargo compartment which is not accompanied by a passenger.

DqzJF8gZ.question: What is meant by the term 'unidentified baggage' when referring to (EC) No 300/**2008**) or ICAO Annex 17?

options.text: Baggage at an airport, with or without a baggage tag, which is not picked up by or identified with a passenger.
Baggage that has been left in the baggage reclaim area and not collected within 72 hours
Baggage that has been left in the baggage reclaim area and not collected within 24 hours.
Baggage at an airport, without a baggage tag, which is not picked up by or identified with a passenger.

etZcIXQ5.question: Each Contracting State shall take appropriate measures for the safety of passengers and crew of an aircraft which is subjected to an act of unlawful interference, while on the ground in the territory of the Contracting State..

options.text: until their journey can be continued.
and must arrange for the passengers and crew to be returned to their country of origin.
during a period of investigation.
if this is requested by any individual passengers.

yp7vyHaq.question: Each Contracting State shall take appropriate measures for the safety of passengers and crew of an aircraft which is subjected to an act of unlawful interference, while on the ground in the territory of the Contracting State...

options.text: until their journey can be continued.
and must arrange for the passengers and crew to be returned to their country of origin.
during a period of investigation.
if this is requested by any individual passengers.

tx11AfJi.question: When a member State allows police officers, security staff, bodyguards or other agents of foreign states to carry weapons in their territory for the protection of aircraft in flight, permission for the carriage of weapons should be conditional upon:

options.text: prior notification by the State of embarkation to the foreign State in which the weapons will be carried on the airport of arrival and notification of the pilot-in-command of a decision to permit a weapon to be carried on board his aircraft.
agreement between the State of embarkation and the State of destination.
notification of the pilot-in-command of a decision to permit a weapon to be carried on board his aircraft only.
agreement between the State of embarkation and the airport of arrival.

5ucYFwPj.question: According to ICAO Annex 17, following an unlawful interference, who shall take adequate measures for the safety of passengers and crew of an aircraft, until their journey can be continued?

options.text: The contracting State where the aircraft is located.
The aircraft`s operator.
The commander of the aircraft.
EASA

S9u6YsOw.question: According to ICAO Annex 17, following an unlawful interference, who shall take adequate measures for the safety of passengers and crew of an aircraft, until their journey can be continued?

options.text: The contracting State where the aircraft is located.
The aircraft`s operator.
EASA.
The commander of the aircraft.

TTEkFia5.question: According to ICAO Annex 17, following an unlawful interference, who shall take adequate measures for the safety of passengers and crew of an aircraft, until their journey can be continued?

options.text: 4 only

rE98A16G.question: What should a pilot do if his/her aircraft is subject to an act of unlawful interference and contact to an ATS unit cannot be established?

options.text: attempt to broadcast warnings on the VHF channel in use or the VHF emergency frequency (e.g. 121.5 MHz).
proceed at a level which differs from the cruising levels normally used for IFR flight by 150 m (600 ft) in an area where a vertical separation minimum of 600 m (2 000 ft) is applied.
proceed in accordance with applicable special procedures for in-flight contingencies, where such procedures have been established and promulgated in the Regional Supplementary Procedures (Doc 7300).
proceed at a level which differs from the cruising levels normally used for IFR flight by 250 m (700 ft) in an area where a vertical separation minimum of 300 m (1 000 ft) is applied.

z7KBzKUY.question: What should a pilot do if his/her aircraft is subject to an act of unlawful interference and contact to an ATS unit cannot be established?

options.text: proceed at a level which differs from the cruising levels normally used for IFR flight by 150 m (500 ft) in an area where a vertical separation minimum of 300 m (1 000 ft) is applied.
proceed at a level which differs from the cruising levels normally used for IFR flight by 200 m (600 ft) in an area where a vertical separation minimum of 600 m (2 000 ft) is applied.
never attempt to broadcast warnings on the VHF channel (e.g. 121.5 MHz).
proceed in accordance with applicable special procedures for in-flight contingencies, where such procedures have been established and promulgated in the Regional Supplementary Procedures (Doc 7130).

w99bQdmp.question: What should a pilot do if his/her aircraft is subject to an act of unlawful interference and contact to an ATS unit cannot be established?

options.text: proceed at a level which differs from the cruising levels normally used for IFR flight by 300 m (1 000 ft) in an area where a vertical separation minimum of 600 m (2 000 ft) is applied.
proceed at a level which differs from the cruising levels normally used for IFR flight by 200 m (600 ft) in an area where a vertical separation minimum of 300 m (1 000 ft) is applied.
proceed in accordance with applicable special procedures for in-flight contingencies, where such procedures have been established and promulgated in the Regional Supplementary Procedures (Doc 7 300).
attempt to broadcast warnings only on the HF channel.

5dCDN357.question: What should a pilot do if his/her aircraft is subject to an act of unlawful interference and contact to an ATS unit cannot be established?

options.text: proceed in accordance with applicable special procedures for in-flight contingencies, where such procedures have been established and promulgated in the Regional Supplementary Procedures (Doc 7030).
never attempt to broadcast warnings on the VHF channel (e.g. 121.5 MHz).
proceed at a level which differs from the cruising levels normally used for IFR flight by 200 m (600 ft) in an area where a vertical separation minimum of 300 m (1 000 ft) is applied.
proceed at a level which differs from the cruising levels normally used for IFR flight by 150 m (500 ft) in an area where a vertical separation minimum of 600 m (2 000 ft) is applied.

0st1u7cq.question: What should a pilot do if his/her aircraft is subjected to an act of unlawful interference and contact to an ATS unit cannot be established?

options.text: Proceed at a level which differs from the cruising levels normally used for IFR by 500 ft in an area where a vertical separation minimum of 1 000 ft is applied.
Proceed at a level which differs from the cruising levels normally used for IFR by 2 000 ft in an area where a vertical separation minimum of 1 300 ft is applied.
Proceed at a level which differs from the cruising levels normally used for IFR by 1 000 ft in an area where a vertical separation minimum of 500 ft is applied.
Proceed at a level which differs from the cruising levels normally used for IFR by 1 000 ft in an area where a vertical separation minimum of 1 000 ft is applied.

7U3fEpFE.question: What is meant by the term 'screening' when referring to (EC) No 300/**2008**) or ICAO Annex 17?

options.text: Detecting weapons and explosives which could be used to commit hijacks and other acts of unlawful interference.
Using X-rays to detect drugs and similar substances.
Moving suspicious baggage or cargo behind a safety screen in the passenger area for isolation and security purposes.
Moving suspicious baggage or cargo airside, away from passengers.

E9Pw6gxR.question: What is meant by the term 'screening' when referring to (EC) No 300/**2008**) or ICAO Annex 17?

options.text: The application of technical or other means which are intended to identify and/or detect prohibited articles.
The checking of passengers if they are allowed to enter the state of destination.
A check if pilots are fit for flight.
The application of radar to detect aircraft flying overhead prohibited areas.
